fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • When writing about legal proceedings, we have sometimes been misusing the term "burden of proof". For instance, reporting an inquest jury's finding that London newspaper vendor Ian Tomlinson was unlawfully killed during the G20 protests of 2009, a story said: "The jury had to be satisfied 'beyond reasonable doubt' … the same burden of proof that would be applied in a criminal trial" (PC who struck Tomlinson could face trial, 4 May, page 3 turned from page 1). In another instance, an article said that the verdict of a German court – that John Demjanjuk was an accessory to the murder of thousands of Jewish captives at Sobibor death camp in occupied Poland during the second world war – had "lowered the burden of proof" in such cases because it was based on evidence proving only that Demjanjuk worked as an SS guard at the camp, not that he had committed a specific crime (After 68 years, Nazi guard found guilty over his role in deaths of 28,000 Jews, 13 May, page 19). What these stories were actually referring to is the "standard of proof" that must be met for a decision in law to be reached. By contrast, the "burden of proof" is the requirement resting on a plaintiff or defendant to prove the facts of the case. • An article on the saving of the art deco Majestic, one of Africa's first cinemas, inadvertently referred to Dar es Salaam as Tanzania's capital. The official capital is Dodoma, although the much larger Dar es Salaam remains the commercial capital (Saving the Majestic – Zanzibar's lost screen gem, 3 June, page 23).
